title: SUSANNA REID: I was mugged at knifepoint. Now I'm terrified for my teenage sons
text:
There’s a unique feeling of terror when you’re threatened with a knife. I felt it years ago on a quiet street near my home in Stockwell, South London.

A young man came out of nowhere and grabbed my handbag. Rather than sensibly let him get away, I responded to the adrenaline surging through my body and raced after him, shouting.

We stared at each other briefly, and in that moment I genuinely believe he was more scared than me. He ran off with the £60 I’d just taken from a cashpoint, leaving my bag, Nokia brick phone and house keys.

As I picked up the handbag, I realised it had been cut and looked down to see a wide tear in my heavy raincoat. He’d slashed at my clothes with a knife to get my bag — the blade millimetres from my skin. He could so easily have turned the knife against me when I chased him.

Susanna Reid (pictured) who was mugged at knifepoint in South London, calls for an investment in young people at risk of getting involved in the epidemic

Afterwards, there was basically nothing police could do. Overwhelmed by fear and fury, I couldn’t identify the boy. I felt useless, and sensed the police were frustrated, but I was simply too shocked.

For months afterwards I feared anyone walking close to me on the street, totally losing my trust.

I am now the mother of three teenage boys living in South London, not far from the site of that attack. Knife crime is far worse, and lives are being lost on a frightening scale. As I write, four young men are on trial for the murder of 17-year-old Girl Scout Jodie Chesney in a London park.

The news of each latest stabbing — like the two 17-year-olds killed in Milton Keynes at the weekend — makes me fear for my boys whenever they step out of the door. And how is the Mayor of London, Sadiq Khan, spending his time? Well, over the weekend, as mums like me worried about letting their children out on the streets, he joined protesters in a march — to campaign for a second referendum on Brexit.

Sadiq is proud of having invested £15 million a year on a violence reduction unit and £7 million on projects combating youth violence. But that pales in comparison to the £130 million this country would pay for the referendum he was marching for. Not to mention the £37 million being spent on policing Extinction Rebellion.

I know Sadiq — he is a father himself, he lives near me and I believe in his heart he is concerned about knife crime. But I was deeply disappointed to see him distracted from what he claims is his top priority, keeping Londoners safe.

Last month a teenager was jailed for killing 17-year-old Malcolm Mide-Madariola outside Clapham South station, practically on my doorstep. Malcolm was a peacemaker, standing up for a friend. He was stabbed with a 12 in hunting knife.

Susanna revealed Sadiq Khan (pictured centre) is among those who say solving the epidemic of knife crime will take a generation

In the wake of his death I interviewed Sadiq on Good Morning Britain. Barely able to hold in my tears, I demanded he tell parents how we could feel our children are safe. He insisted violent crime in the capital was being addressed. I wanted to believe him, but every time a young person is killed, those words ring in my ears.

Knife crime has reached a record high across England and Wales, new figures show, with 44,000 incidents in the year to June — up 7 per cent.

It’s not hard to join the dots on what’s causing this. How could the Government think getting rid of 20,000 frontline police officers across the UK over the past eight years was a good idea? In London, numbers dropped to a 15-year low. The Tories have promised to recruit 20,000 new police officers but that needs to happen fast.

Off-air gossip Shouty Piers is off GMB for half-term, replaced by the gentle tones of Ben Shephard. Ben is full of surprises: he once had a cameo in Friends, and appeared in Harry Potter And The Half-Blood Prince. My only role was in animated Justin Timberlake movie Trolls. But as I played his GRANDMOTHER . . . it’s not one I’m putting on my CV!

We need a pincer movement to tackle crime — and its causes. Restoring police budgets across the country must come first.

We must also invest in young people at risk, to keep them on the straight and narrow. Otherwise gangs are only too happy to step into the gap. Youth clubs are vital as are programmes like Divert, which works with under-25s who have been arrested.

The crime against me was fleeting. I lost just a small amount of money, a degree of trust and a raincoat. But I am broken by the agony of those who have suffered the worst. The loss of a child, a sibling, a parent.

To those including Sadiq Khan who say solving the epidemic of knife crime will take a generation. Sorry, but our children don’t have that long. And they deserve better.

Jennifer Aniston told her co-star Reese Witherspoon (pictured together) that the secret of her slim figure is celery juice

No celery juice on my morning show!

Jennifer Aniston’s revealed the secret of her slim figure at 50. Celery juice. Jen shared her healthy advice with friend and co-star Reese Witherspoon, who’s a convert.

That’s the kind of good influence every woman needs. The pair are co-starring in The Morning Show, about a daily news programme.

Wish I could ask my co-hosts for diet tips — but I’d be eating Laura Tobin’s Haribos, Kate Garraway’s chocolates and Piers Morgan’s banana sandwiches. And something tells me I wouldn’t end up looking like Jennifer Aniston.

Why does everyone keep on blubbing?

Will and Janette (pictured) had waterworks with their performance on week five of Strictly

Week five on Strictly and the waterworks were in full flow as Will and Janette performed their frankly gorgeous Couple’s Choice dance.

Last week it was Katya who broke down in tears when she and ‘Magic’ Mike Bushell got through their Quickstep without falling over.

This week Mike went from Magic to Tragic and ended up in the dance-off — cue another emotional week, I’m sure. So why can’t they all just stop blubbing?

I remember, when I first signed up for the show, a friend warning me not to get sucked into the ‘Strictly Bubble’.

Well good luck with that. Strictly becomes the centre of your world because you work at it so intensely.

It’s a kind of madness —then come Christmas the bubble bursts and you’re left scratching your head, wondering what got you so worked up.

This week’s guilty click

Susanna revealed that she's currently a fan of Lakeland’s Hot Chocolate Melt (pictured)

Hot chocolate melt from Lakeland, £2.99

As the cold weather bites, I’m salivating over Lakeland’s Hot Chocolate Melt — a hollow ball of chocolate you pour hot milk over to create a tasty warming drink.

The ball’s outer coating melts — and then the mini marshmallows inside float to the top like magic. Who can resist a clever hot choc at this time of year?
description: Susanna Reid was mugged at knifepoint a few years ago in Stockwell, South London. Mother-of-three teenage sons, calls for an investment in young people who are at risk of getting involved in crime.
authors: Susanna Reid For The Daily Mail
